basics.name: Basem Jawahri
basics.label: Senior Front End Developer
basics.summary: I am a front end developer with over fifteen years of experience in technology looking for opportunities at companies that are vibrant, energetic and willing to embrace cutting edge technology. I have the technical knowhow to pick up new technology and methodologies and a keen eye for good code.

work.summary: Contracting under my own limited company.

projects.title: Swordfish Advertising - Unify Health App (January 2021 - March 2021)
projects.description: Unify Health is an for people living with cancer. It helps you locate and speak to community pharmacists, track your symptoms, set reminders for medication and more. I was part of a team that built the Unify Health App using React native, expo-cli, Saga and Redux store for data flow.

projects.title: Centrica - British Gas (September 2018 - December 2019)
projects.description: I was a part of the home services team, responsible for driving over 72% of the online business revenue. I was one of three senior front end developers on this team. Starting at Centrica, I learned and used Ember.js within a few days. For everything we did in the team we applied test driven development with the use of Qunit and Yadda to write acceptance, integration and unit tests. We used the Wunderflow Git workflow along with continuous integration and continuous deployment within a two week sprint cycle. I was involved in a team working on a greenfield project to allow British Gas service customers modify, cancel or renew their contract online. This involved communication with AWS hosted. My teams main responsibility was the day to day maintenance and feature building of the services acquisition app which drove over 72% of the British Gas online revenue. I was responsible for building and maintaining a campaign redeem app on that went on to process 12,000 customers in the first month of its release.

projects.title: MRM McCAN - TommeeTippee (August 2018 - September 2018)
projects.description: TommeeTippee as a client of MRM wanted to improve their site performance, add an arabic language for their Middle East customers and get a review of their existing code for which I was assigned to. As well as implementation of the new features/improvements, I provided TommeeTippee with a detailed report.

projects.title: ORM Digital (June 2017 - October 2017)
projects.description: ORM is an award-winning digital strategy agency with a particular focus on providing Sitecore solutions. In my time working at ORM I was involved in multiple projects such as Arriva Chiltern Railways, South Western Railway, Transpennine Express and Great Western Railway. The work varied between Knockout.js, Angular.js and pure ES6 with a component based architecture. This is a fast paced environment where quite often switching between projects is required. My main focus here was the timely delivery of the SWR project for which I also ran client training and delivering a refactored ticket booking system for GWR which we moved from knockout to angular.

projects.title: DurableDigital - The Ford Foundation (October 2016 - January 2017)
projects.description: The Ford Foundation is an independent, non-profit grant-making organization and the second largest philanthropy in the United States. I was involved in a revamp of their website, working closely with back-end, design and QA. The solution is built on an Umbraco platform with an angular client side presenting translatable views. The grant-making database consumes data from a REST API and translates that data into a single page application where charts are drawn to represent the data given. These charts interact with other parts of the solution combining the data provided by the service and data provided by the CMS.

projects.title: Avanade UK - Vodafone Digital Workplace (March 2016 - August 2016)
projects.description: Developed the Vodafone Digital Workplace for Vodafone internal use which consisted of a collection of provider hosted SharePoint apps in Office 365. The workplace is used by over 100,000 Vodafone employees globally and supported in sixteen languages. The client side is a SPA built on Angular with a per client customizable grid like the Windows tiles but more options in app dimensions. The workplace is where each user can add, remove, reposition and resize any of the apps within the Vodafone app store. The app store is also part of this build where each app is a separate module that interacts with the workspace and sibling modules. In the styling front, everything is mobile first HTML5/CSS3 with considerations for touch events.

work.summary: Member of the core migration team to redesign and redevelop the sister website on the Salesforce platform. As well as the day to day development I was responsible for running the FE meetings and for a short time acted as scrum master for my team.

projects.title: VisionDirect/GlassesDirect Salesforce and legacy Magento
projects.description: I was involved in maintaining the legacy Magento sites for Vision Direct and Glasses Direct as well as the redesign and migration of the legacy websites to the new Salesforce platform.

projects.title: Component Depot
projects.description: Because of the limitations presented to us by the Salesforce platform, I created a project that built the components as web components. This enabled us to share components between projects, reduce duplication and most importantly allowed for unit testing as well as integration testing.

work.summary: For three years at JustGiving I was part of a growing team of eleven front end developers in an agile environment and was fortunate enough to be allocated to some of the very important parts of the website. Some of the areas which I was able to work on included the Charity landing pages, the user profile page, the homepages and two versions of the donation process. While working on these projects, I had the opportunity to lead the path to a responsive web experience and to create a new style guide for future use and maintenance of the JustGiving brand. I was able to map out a monolith and come up with a plan on how we can distribute and unify the new style guide/component library. Part of this plan was to bring all CMS content into one platform with a flexible layout configuration.

projects.title: Homepage
projects.description: The homepage was built with Angular.js and served a logged in and a logged out state. With this project there was an emphasis on performance as well as strong UX decisions. The logged in state had an instagram-like infinite scrolling with featured cards. This project also carried with it the redesign of the header/navigation to a responsive design and hosted on AWS as a separate component.

projects.title: One click donation
projects.description: The one click donation process was built on top of the existing donation process with knockout.js which allowed logged in visitors to donate with the least friction possible. This project involved a lot of A/B testing and analytics which saw an 11% rise in donations.

projects.title: Charity Landing page
projects.description: The charity landing page was the number one entry page to the website. This page was very important in terms of visitor engagement and retention. I was involved in redesigning and moving of this page from the legacy code to an AWS hosted responsive layout. I took charge during this project the drive to move to a responsive layout which led to the development of the JustGiving style-guide.

projects.title: Sysdoc
projects.description: SharePoint intranet solution for a client of Sysdoc using SharePoint designer.

projects.title: ByeBye London
projects.description: Sitecore solution for ByeBye London, an advertising agency and tour guide catalogue to digitize it's operation.

projects.title: West9properties
projects.description: Creating a web presence for an estate agency using Umbraco CMS providing viewings scheduler.

work.summary: I started my front end developer career at ClearPeople.

projects.title: National Autistic Society
projects.description: Accessibility and browser compatibility were very important to this client due to the nature of its target audience which meant that fall-backs were always put in place for new features and thorough testing was done before any deployment. As the front end lead, I was in charge of planning the structure and setting up the Sitecore page layouts, sub-layouts and what we called “blocks” for this very flexible site. The blocks can be setup differently and placed within the homepage or any other page, including the e-commerce and checkout process pages. This also applies to the Sitecore modules used on the site such as the web forms for marketer’s module styled to fit anywhere the client wished. Along with this flexibility came the risk of site editors making mistakes so I was in charge of the Sitecore security setup on the solution based on inheritance of roles and domains for the microsites within the setup.

projects.title: SEGA
projects.description: This SEGA project was for a Microsoft SharePoint intranet publishing site with a very challenging design which included a custom jQuery carousel with AJAX functionality, some custom web parts and as much branding of vanilla SharePoint features as possible. With a new master page, page layouts, menus and a lot of customization to the SharePoint ribbon deployed, I was able to go to the client offices and carry out a training session for the new users which included instructions on how to manage the site and the already available social networking features of SharePoint.

projects.title: Stena Lines
projects.description: Stena recognized the opportunity to upgrade the websites of four of their business units from Microsoft CMS 2002 to SharePoint 2010. This was to be done in a manner that the transition was seamless to the site visitors. Rather than migrating all of the styling from the previous solution, we brought in what was relevant and cleaned it up. A lot of this was then modified in order to work with the various SharePoint controls such as the navigation and breadcrumbs etc.
